Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: A Fast and Efficient Power System Dynamic Simulator
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project includes a significant impact on the electric power contingency analysis conducted by industries around the globe. The proposed algorithm can be used by power system planning units, operators, utility companies, universities, and research centers and provides designers, engineers, and scientists with the opportunity of a considerable reduction in computation efforts in performing power grid dynamic simulations, especially in the grids with high penetration of renewable and small-scale generators. It allows conducting more studies in shorter time and leads to significant personnel and equipment cost reduction. In addition, the proposed algorithm is a significant step forward towards realizing a real-time power system analyzer, which can be used to alleviate the adverse effects of faults and disturbances in small and large electric power systems. Thus, the proposed algorithm potentially helps enhance modern power system reliability and resiliency by providing a fast and accurate analysis of the system under various possible contingencies. As the power grid is one of the most important and fundamental infrastructures in each society, the proposed project will directly enhance social welfare.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will develop a software program for dynamic analysis of power grids. In electric power industries, grid simulators are vital tools to evaluate and analyze dynamic behavior of the grid. Power grids are large-scale networks that are mathematically modeled by thousands of variables and equations. Analysis of such a large number of variables and equations is very time-consuming. Integration of intermittent renewable energy resources as well as small-scale low-inertia generators to modern power grids make the network analysis even more challenging. In the proposed algorithm (to become a software program) a novel mathematical solver is proposed that significantly reduces the computations required to solve the well-known differential-algebraic equations describing power systems. The proposed algorithm contributes to the reduction of the size of the Jacobian matrix and removal of the error loop in the power grid dynamic simulations. These improvements significantly increase the speed of the proposed software program in analyzing dynamic behavior of power grids when compared to the available methods. Preliminary studies show that the proposed power grid simulator can perform at least 30 times faster than the standard Newton-Raphson algorithm when simulating large grids with significant number of generators.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electric energy is the most convenient and vital source of energy in the modern day. Stability of the power system is of paramount importance for the secure and reliable energy delivery. While significant amount of energy is transferred from the generators to the customers in a constant pace, a small amount of imbalance between generation and consumption, which can be caused by disturbances, load changes, etc., can be detrimental to the power system stability. Consequently, utility companies must perform extensive simulating studies to assure that the power system will operate safely under variety of disturbances and make necessary changes and remedies ahead of time. Such studies take significant amount of time and labor with available tools. An innovative algorithm is proposed and evaluated to increase the speed of dynamic simulators for large-scale power systems. Such simulators solve a set of differential-algebraic equations for power systems comprising thousands of nodes and power lines as well as hundreds of generators. With the introduction of intermittent renewable energy systems power systems become more prone to instability when the share of the intermittent power generation such as solar or wind becomes significant, which in turn increases the demand for faster dynamic simulators.

The proposed algorithm can increase the speed of the power system dynamic simulation studies. The efforts put into by the project team include creating a C++ code that runs the proposed algorithm, improving numerical solution speed, enhancing power system model, evaluating the accuracy and speed of the algorithm via running about 320 simulation tests on two standard large-scale power networks, and customer outreach in the 18-month project period.

Intellectual merits. The proposed algorithm gives sufficiently accurate results with time steps four times greater than that of the available software programs in the market. This can increase the simulation speed up to four times compared to the available simulators. The proposed algorithm has adequate accuracy for majority of test cases pertinent to power system dynamic studies. The proposed approach does not provide correct results for bolted faults on the generator buses. In some cases, the algorithm outperforms its competitor. The use of appropriate solution methods and programing tools along with proper compilers helped increase the speed of the created C code; however, more improvement is still needed in the arithmetic to achieve the predicted speed. The team was able to achieve significant speed through modifications in the subroutines.

Market. Utility sector is a potential customer if the speed barriers are fully resolved. Another approach for commercializing the proposed algorithm is partnership with one of the vendors of such software producers. This way, the core algorithm developed in the STTR Phase I can use the advanced tools developed by the current vendors and thus speed up their simulators by four times.

Broader impact. The developed algorithm solves differential-algebraic equations for very large-scale systems in an innovative way that is much faster than the available solutions. Thus, any large-scale application that is represented by such equations can benefit from the developed algorithm. Faster solution achieved by the algorithm makes comprehensive studies easier and with lower cost. This in turn helps secure the reliable delivery of electric power in the presence of disturbances such as failures and intermittency of loads and renewable generation and facilitates the usage of renewable energy systems.

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2018
Modified by: Omidreza Nazaripouya

Stability of the power system is of paramount importance for the secure and reliable energy delivery. Such simulators solve a set of differential-algebraic equations for power systems comprising thousands of nodes and power lines as well as hundreds of generators.
